How to: choose or select
07 Nov 2019, 10:00 by Linda Zhuravleva
It all depends on the mood of the verb.
To write a word correctly, you need to determine the shade of its meaning. If a verb expresses advice, a wish, a request or an order, then we are dealing with an imperative mood. It is formed using the suffix -i-. For example: Choose one correct answer.
If the word denotes a real action that takes place, has occurred or will occur, then we have a indicative mood. That it is most often found in speech. In it, the verbs vary in tenses, numbers, persons and gender.
In the future tense of the indicative mood you should write only choose. For example: When you select a dish, call the waiter. In most unstressed personal endings of the verbs of the first conjugation, * the letter e is written. And choosing a verb just fits this rule. * Source: Gramota.ru: writing unstressed endings of verbs
